message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical findings suggest a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a communication between the left and right ventricles. The harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex are typical for a VSD. Communication between the pulmonary artery and the thoracic aorta (a patent ductus arteriosus) would cause a continuous murmur, not a holosystolic one. Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum (an atrial septal defect) would present with a fixed split second heart sound and a wide, fixed split between S2 and preceding systole. Right ventricular outflow obstruction (pulmonary stenosis or tetralogy of Fallot) would present with a crescendo-decrescendo ejection systolic murmur over the upper to mid-left sternal border, not a holosystolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical findings (grade 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex) suggest a ventricular septal defect (VSD) which is a left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. Communication between the pulmonary artery and thoracic aorta (option A) is seen in patent ductus arteriosus. Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum (option B) is seen in atrial septal defect. Right ventricular outflow obstruction (option D) is seen in pulmonary stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a loud, harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border suggests a ventricular septal defect, which causes a left-to-right shunt. A communication between the pulmonary artery and the thoracic aorta, or a right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum or right ventricular outflow obstruction would not produce the same murmur in this location.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex suggests a left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. Communication between the pulmonary artery and the thoracic aorta would present with a continuous murmur, and right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum would present with a fixed split second heart sound. Right ventricular outflow obstruction would present with systolic ejection murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, which is characteristic of ventricular septal defect (VSD), a common congenital heart defect. The soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex may be due to increased blood flow across the mitral valve. This is consistent with left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. None of the other options explain VSD or left-to-right shunt.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border is a classic finding for ventricular septal defect (VSD), which leads to left-to-right shunt. The soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex is also consistent with VSD. Communication between the pulmonary artery and the thoracic aorta will cause a continuous murmur, not a holosystolic one. A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum will cause a cyanotic heart defect and is not consistent with the physical findings. Right ventricular outflow obstruction will cause a systolic ejection murmur, not a holosystolic one.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border suggests a left-to-right shunt through a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex could correspond to the flow of blood from the left atrium to the left ventricle. Communication between the pulmonary artery and the thoracic aorta would result in a continuous murmur. Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum would not cause a harsh holosystolic murmur, and right ventricular outflow obstruction would not cause a left-to-right shunt.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex suggest a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a type of left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. Communication between the pulmonary artery and the thoracic aorta would cause a continuous murmur. A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum would cause a fixed splitting of S2. Right ventricular outflow obstruction would cause a harsh systolic ejection murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex suggest a ventricular septal defect, which is a type of left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. Communications between the pulmonary artery and the thoracic aorta (option A) is a patent ductus arteriosus, which presents as a machinery-like murmur heard in systole or continuous. Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum (option B) is an atrial septal defect, which usually has a wide fixed split S2. Right ventricular outflow obstruction (option D) is pulmonary stenosis, which presents as an ejection systolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The grade 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex is highly indicative of a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a left-to-right shunt. Communication between the pulmonary artery and the thoracic aorta is seen in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and is indicated by a continuous murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border. Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum is seen in atrial septal defect (ASD) and is indicated by a fixed, widely split second heart sound. Right ventricular outflow obstruction is seen in pulmonary stenosis and is indicated by a systolic ejection click at the left upper sternal border.
